results.title: Digital Storytelling workshop : general public (September 2008)
results.brief_description: Eight members of the general public in Melbourne create stories about the things the resonate strongly with them, whether that is the sense of home, the love of family or cherished memories.
results.description: Eight members of the general public in Melbourne create stories about the things the resonate strongly with them, whether that is the sense of home, the love of family or cherished memories.

results.title: Mayaro boy Melbourne girl
results.creator_credit: Kate Watson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kate Watson weaves a romantic tale of enduring love, of two travellers who met and followed each other around the world throughout the years.

results.title: Getting off map 30
results.creator_credit: Anna Poletti, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: For the fourteen years that Anna Poletti has lived in Melbourne, her various residences have had one thing in common - you can locate them all on map 30 of the Melways street directory. She pays homage to the streets and intersections of her neighbourhood.

results.title: Zea
results.creator_credit: Jean-Jacques Leduc, Andre Leduc, Robert Forget and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A superb visual trick that will mystify its audience, this animated film transforms the commonplace into magic. The film presented a serious technical challenge because the subject was both elusive and explosive. A film to watch, enjoy and laugh about. (Awards: Cannes; Chicago; Elmhurst; Columbus; Paris; Genie, Toronto.) Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Forgotten corner
results.creator_credit: Samara McIlroy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘A little further up the road and a little further into the wilderness than you think.’ Samara McIlroy pays loving tribute to her special corner of Victoria, a place where you can still drop in for a ‘cuppa’ without ringing first.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Samara McIlroy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Trial (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Alexander Salkind, Orson Welles, Fl. C. It., Hisa-Film and Paris-Europa Productions
results.brief_description: Welles neglected masterpiece is a stunning adaptation of Franz Kafka’s existential novel about a man who is caught in an increasingly bizarre and sinister bureaucratic world. One morning K (Anthony Perkins) is awoken by the police who have come to arrest him on a charge that no-one will explain. As the innocent K becomes more and more entangled in the nightmare of bureaucracy he slowly assumes the guilty role that he has been accused off. Filmed in black and white and in a style that recalls the experiments of expressionism, “The Trial” is both a rare successful film version of a uniquely literary work as well as an important and underrated film in Welles’ oeuvre. Cast includes Jeanne Moreau, Romy Schneider, Elsa Martinelli, Orson Welles, Akim Tamiroff.

results.title: The Trench
results.creator_credit: William Boyd, Christophe Barratier, Jacques Perrin, Steve Clark-Hall, Canal+, Galatee Films, Skyline Films, Blue PM, Bonaparte Films and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Set in 1916 in the Somme Valley, Northern France, “The Trench” tells of the 48 hours leading up to the bloody Battle of the Somme where 60,000 young British soldiers tragically lost their lives fighting the German enemy. The story unfolds through the eyes of seventeen year-old Billy MacFarlane (Paul Nicholls) who joined the Army to fight alongside his older brother Eddie (Tam Williams). The focus of the film is mainly confined to the “trench”, an eight foot wide, six hundred mile long man-made place from hell, where the Platoon and their Captain, Telford Winter (Daniel Craig), wait for the battle to begin. Reality hits when Eddie is hit by sniper fire and Billy’s platoon is ordered to go with the first wave of attack. “The Trench” is novelist William Boyd’s directorial debut. Cast also includes Julian Rhind-Tutt, Danny Dyer, James D’arcy, Antony Strachan, Michael Moreland.

results.title: The Tree that remembers (D)
results.creator_credit: Masoud Raouf and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1992 a young Iranian student and an ex-prisoner of war under the Ayatollah’s regime during the 80’s, hanged himself on the outskirts of a small town in Canada. Director Masoud Raouf, also an ex-prisoner under the Ayatollah regime has sought to address and understand the inherent long-term issues surrounding the survival of ex-political prisoners and asylum seekers, raising issues of cultural integration and disparity between Western cultures and refugees generally whilst giving air to subjects usually silent within Western communities. A group of former prisoners in Iran elucidate on their personal experiences describing the horrors of torture and imprisonment and the means in which they survived spiritually throughout their detainment. “Boxing” a form of solitary confinement is described in detail with its psychological effect - a form of torture that mimics the corpse in order to break the spirit.

results.title: The Treasure of Sierra Madre
results.creator_credit: John Huston, Henry Blanke and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: John Huston won Academy Awards both as director and writer of this film. Based on B. Traven’s novel, it reveals the effects of greed and the lure of sudden wealth on three penniless prospectors. Humphrey Bogart, as Fred C. Dobbs, gives one of the best performances of his career. We watch him change from a likeable drifter into a man capable of killing his best friend in cold blood.
